facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 990 of 1964 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal No. 990 of 1964.

facts.text: Appeal is from the judgment and decree dated April 15, 1963 of the Allahabad High Court, Lucknow Bench.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated April 15, 1963 of the Allahabad High Court, Lucknow Bench in First Appeal from Order No. 30 of 1960.

facts.text: High Court appeal was First Appeal from Order No. 30 of 1960.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from Order No. 30 of 1960.

facts.text: An agreement was entered into between the appellant and the respondents on May 20, 1965 referring certain differences to arbitration of three persons.

anchor.surface_text: On May 20, 1965, an agreement was entered into between the appellant and the respondents referring certain differences between them to the arbitration of three persons.

facts.text: An award was made on January 19, 1956, signed by two out of three arbitrators as the third refused to sign.

anchor.surface_text: On January 19, 1956, an award was made, signed by two out of the three arbitrators as the third arbitrator had refused to sign the award.

facts.text: The award was filed in court on September 7, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: The award was filed in court on September 7, 1957 and the respondents prayed for a decree in accordance with the award.

facts.text: Respondents prayed for a decree in accordance with the award after filing.

anchor.surface_text: and the respondents prayed for a decree in accordance with the award.

facts.text: Notice of filing of the award was issued to the appellant and served on September 30, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: Notice of filing of the award was issued to the appellant and was served upon him on September 30, 1957.

facts.text: Appellant filed an objection on November 3, 1957 attacking validity of the award on various grounds.

anchor.surface_text: On November 3, 1957, the appellant filed an objection in the nature of a written statement. By this objection the appellant attacked the validity of the award on various grounds.

facts.text: The objection had 43 paragraphs but no prayer at the end indicating desired relief.

anchor.surface_text: But the objection did not contain any prayer at the end, nor did it indicate what relief the appellant desired, though there were as many as 43 paragraphs therein.

facts.text: Respondents contended that the objection was an application to set aside the award under s.30 of the Act and barred by limitation as filed more than 30 days after notice.

anchor.surface_text: When the matter came to be heard in the trial court, the respondents contended that the so-called objection was in the nature of an application to set aside the award and contained grounds coming under s. 30 of the Arbitration Act... it was barred by limitation under Art. 158 of the Indian Limitation Act.

facts.text: Trial court held appellant's objection not maintainable as remedy was to apply under s.33, and it was filed more than 30 days after notice.

anchor.surface_text: The trial court held that the appellants objection was not maintainable, as his remedy was to apply under s. 33 of the Act, if he wanted the award to be set aside on the grounds raised in the objection. As he had not done so and as the objection was itself filed more than 30 days after the service of notice on him, he was barred from raising any ground for setting aside the award which fell under S. 30 of the Act.

facts.text: Trial court held objection could not be treated as application under s.33 due to being beyond 30 days.

anchor.surface_text: The trial court also held that the objection could not be treated as an application under s. 33 of the Act in view of the fact that it was beyond 30 days as required by Art. 158 of the Limitation Act.

facts.text: Trial court passed a decree in terms of the award.

anchor.surface_text: The trial court therefore passed a decree in terms of the award.

facts.text: Appellant appealed to the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then went in appeal to the High Court,

facts.text: Main question in High Court: whether appellant could maintain objection without application under s.33.

anchor.surface_text: and the main question urged there was whether the appellant could maintain his objection when he had failed to make an application under s. 33 of the Act for setting aside the award on grounds contained in the objection.

facts.text: High Court held award could not be set aside on s.30 grounds except by application under s.33 within 30 days.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court came to the conclusion that the award could not be set aside on grounds which fell under s. 30 of the Act, except on an application under s. 33 of the Act within thirty days of the service of notice of filing of the award as required by Art. 158 of the Limitation Act.

facts.text: High Court held appellant's objection could not be treated as s.33 application as barred by time.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court further held that the objection of the appellant could not be treated as an application under s. 33, as, if it was treated as such application, it would be barred by time.

facts.text: High Court dismissed the appeal but granted certificate to appeal to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court therefore dismissed the appeal, but granted a certificate to the appellant to appeal to this Court.

facts.text: Supreme Court appeal heard on main question and dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: We have heard learned counsel for the appellant on the main. question raised in the High Court. We are of opinion that this appeal must fail.

facts.text: Objections raised by appellant were covered by s.30 of the Act, not in dispute.

anchor.surface_text: It is not in dispute in the present case that the objections raised by the appellant were covered by S. 30 of the Act,

facts.text: Appellant did not pray for setting aside the award in objection but that is what he wanted.

anchor.surface_text: and though the appellant did not pray for setting aside the award in his objection that was what he really wanted the court to do after hearing his objection.

facts.text: Objection filed more than 30 days after notice.

anchor.surface_text: As in the present case the objection was filed more than 30 days after the notice it could not be treated as an application for setting the award, for it would then be barred by limitation.

facts.text: No application to set aside award on s.30 grounds within limitation period.

anchor.surface_text: The position thus is that in the present case there was no application to set aside the award as grounds mentioned in S. 30 within the period of limitation

facts.text: Allahabad High Court granted certificate for appeal to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal on a certificate granted by the Allahabad High Court and arises in the following circumstances.

arguments.claim: Scheme of Act requires application to set aside on s.30 grounds within 30 days; no application made timely.

anchor.surface_text: The Act was passed in 1940 and as the long title shows it is an Act to consolidate and amend the law relating to arbitration. Before 1940, the law relating to arbitration was mainly contained in the Second Schedule to the Code of Civil Procedure, which was repealed by the Act which is not a self-contained code in the matter of arbitration. The scheme of the Act is to divide arbitration into three classes.

arguments.claim: S.17 contemplates application to set aside before pronouncing judgment; grounds in s.30 require application.

anchor.surface_text: s. 14 provides for the award to be signed and filed. When the award is filed the court has to give notice to the parties of the filing of the award under s. 14 2 . Under s. 15, the court is given power to modify or correct an award and under s. 16 the court can remit the award for reconsideration. Section 17 provides for judgment in terms of the award and reads thus - Where the court sees no cause to remit award on any of the matters referred to arbitration for reconsideration or to set aside the award, the court shall, after the time for making an application to set aside the award has expired, or such application having been made, after refusing it, proceed to pronounce judgment according to the award,

arguments.claim: S.32 bars any challenge to award except as provided in Act; must apply under s.30/33 timely.

anchor.surface_text: We may also refer to s. 32 which lays down that notwithstanding any law for the time being in force, no suit shall lie on any ground whatsoever for a decision upon the existence, effect or validity of an arbitration agreement or award, no shall any arbitration agreement or award be set aside, amended, modified or in any way affected otherwise than as provided in this Act

arguments.claim: Late objection cannot be treated as s.33 application if time-barred; no timely challenge on s.30 grounds.

anchor.surface_text: As in the present case the objection was filed more than 30 days after the notice it could not be treated as an application for setting the award, for it would then be barred by limitation. The position thus is that in the present case there was no application to set aside the award as grounds mentioned in S. 30 within the period of limitation

arguments.claim: Any objection falling under s.30 cannot be considered unless within 30 days limitation.

anchor.surface_text: There can be no doubt on the scheme of the Act that any objection even in the nature of a written-statement which falls under s. 30 cannot be considered by the court unless such an objection is made within the period of limitation  namely, 30 days , though if such an objection is made within limitation that objection may in appropriate cases be treated as an application for setting aside the award.

arguments.claim: Suo motu power under s.17 cannot set aside on s.30 grounds via late objection, negates limitation.

anchor.surface_text: Assuming that the court has power to set aside the award suo motu, we are of opinion that power cannot be exercised to set aside an award on grounds which fall under s. 30 of the Act, if taken in an objection petition filed more than 30 days after service of notice of filing of the award, for if that were so the limitation provided under Art. 158 of the Limitation Act would be completely negatived.

arguments.qualifiers: Assuming that the court has power

arguments.claim: Hastimal case only allows suo motu for patent defects not within s.30.

anchor.surface_text: The two cases on which the appellant relies do not in our opinion support him. In Hastimars case 1  it was observed that if the award directs a party to do an act which is prohibited by law or if it is otherwise patently illegal or void it would be open to the court to consider this patent defect in the award suo motu, and when the court acts suo motu no question of limitation prescribed by Art. 158 can arise.

arguments.claim: Saha Co. majority against appellant; minority only for non-s.30 grounds like invalid agreement.

anchor.surface_text: These observations only show that the court can act suo motu in certain circumstances which do not fall within s. 30 of the Act. Saha Co.s case 1  was a decision of five Judges by a majority of 3 2 and the majority judgment is against the appellant. The minority judgment certainly takes the view that the non-existence or invalidity of an arbitration agreement and an order of reference to arbitration may be raised after the period of limitation for the purpose of setting aside an award because they are not grounds for setting aside the award under s. 30.

holdings.text: the objections raised by the appellant were covered by S. 30 of the Act

anchor.surface_text: It is not in dispute in the present case that the objections raised by the appellant were covered by S. 30 of the Act,

anchor.surface_text: There can be no doubt on the scheme of the Act that any objection even in the nature of a written-statement which falls under s. 30 cannot be considered by the court unless such an objection is made within the period of limitation  namely, 30 days , though if such an objection is made within limitation that objection may in appropriate cases be treated as an application for setting aside the award.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Scheme of Arbitration Act mandates timely filing for s.30 objections; timely ones treatable as applications.

anchor.surface_text: Assuming that the court has power to set aside the award suo motu, we are of opinion that power cannot be exercised to set aside an award on grounds which fall under s. 30 of the Act, if taken in an objection petition filed more than 30 days after service of notice of filing of the award, for if that were so the limitation provided under Art. 158 of the Limitation Act would be completely negatived.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Suo motu power under s.17 cannot override limitation for s.30 grounds; would nullify Art.158 purpose.

holdings.text: the court can act suo motu in certain circumstances which do not fall within s. 30 of the Act

anchor.surface_text: In Hastimars case 1  it was observed that if the award directs a party to do an act which is prohibited by law or if it is otherwise patently illegal or void it would be open to the court to consider this patent defect in the award suo motu, and when the court acts suo motu no question of limitation prescribed by Art. 158 can arise. These observations only show that the court can act suo motu in certain circumstances which do not fall within s. 30 of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes Hastimal as limited to patent defects outside s.30 grounds.

holdings.text: where the grounds are not those falling within s. 30, that the award may be set aside on an objection made beyond the period of limitation, even though no application has been made for setting aside the award within the period of limitation. Clearly therefore where an objection as in the present case raises grounds which fall squarely within s. 30 of the Act that objection cannot be heard by the court

anchor.surface_text: The minority judgment certainly takes the view that the non-existence or invalidity of an arbitration agreement and an order of reference to arbitration may be raised after the period of limitation for the purpose of setting aside an award because they are not grounds for setting aside the award under s. 30.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Saha Co. majority rejects late challenges on s.30 grounds; minority limited to non-s.30 issues like invalid agreement.

precedents.citation: Hastimal Dalichand Bora v. Hiralal Motichand Mutha 1

anchor.surface_text: Hastimal Dalichand Bora v. Hiralal Motichand Mutha 1  and Saha Co. v. Ishar Singh Kripal Singh  2 . Assuming that the court has power to set aside the award suo motu, we are of opinion that power cannot be exercised to set aside an award on grounds which fall under s. 30 of the Act, if taken in an objection petition filed more than 30 days after service of notice of filing of the award, for if that were so the limitation provided under Art. 158 of the Limitation Act would be completely negatived. The two cases on which the appellant relies do not in our opinion support him. In Hastimars case 1  it was A.I.R. 1954 Bom. 243.

precedents.citation: Saha Co. v. Ishar Singh Kripal Singh  2

anchor.surface_text: Saha Co. v. Ishar Singh Kripal Singh  2 . Assuming that the court has power to set aside the award suo motu, we are of opinion that power cannot be exercised to set aside an award on grounds which fall under s. 30 of the Act, if taken in an objection petition filed more than 30 days after service of notice of filing of the award, for if that were so the limitation provided under Art. 158 of the Limitation Act would be completely negatived. The two cases on which the appellant relies do not in our opinion support him. In Hastimars case 1  it was A.I.R. 1954 Bom. 243. A.I.R. 1956 Cal. 321. observed that if the award directs a party to do an act which is prohibited by law or if it is otherwise patently illegal or void it would be open to the court to consider this patent defect in the award suo motu

precedents.citation: Hastimars case 1  it was A.I.R. 1954 Bom. 243.

anchor.surface_text: Hastimars case 1  it was A.I.R. 1954 Bom. 243. A.I.R. 1956 Cal. 321. observed that if the award directs a party to do an act which is prohibited by law or if it is otherwise patently illegal or void it would be open to the court to consider this patent defect in the award suo motu, and when the court acts suo motu no question of limitation prescribed by Art. 158 can arise. These observations only show that the court can act suo motu in certain circumstances which do not fall within s. 30 of the Act.

precedents.case_name: Hastimal Dalichand Bora v. Hiralal Motichand Mutha
precedents.cited_proposition: court can act suo motu on patent defects not falling under s.30

anchor.surface_text: A.I.R. 1956 Cal. 321. observed that if the award directs a party to do an act which is prohibited by law or if it is otherwise patently illegal or void it would be open to the court to consider this patent defect in the award suo motu, and when the court acts suo motu no question of limitation prescribed by Art. 158 can arise. These observations only show that the court can act suo motu in certain circumstances which do not fall within s. 30 of the Act. Saha Co.s case 1  was a decision of five Judges by a majority of 3:2 and the majority judgment is against the appellant.

precedents.case_name: Saha Co. v. Ishar Singh Kripal Singh
precedents.cited_proposition: majority and minority views on raising invalidity after limitation
precedents.cited_holding: majority judgment against allowing late objections under s.30; minority allows if not under s.30

anchor.surface_text: Saha Co.s case 1  was a decision of five Judges by a majority of 3:2 and the majority judgment is against the appellant. The minority judgment certainly takes the view that the non-existence or invalidity of an arbitration agreement and an order of reference to arbitration may be raised after the period of limitation for the purpose of setting aside an award because they are not grounds for setting aside the award under s. 30.

precedents.case_name: Saha Co. v. Ishar Singh Kripal Singh
precedents.cited_proposition: grounds not under s.30 can be raised late
late objection on ground of unauthorised filing of award

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that this appeal must fail.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal fails on the main question; objections to the award not maintainable as filed beyond limitation period under s. 33 read with s. 30 of the Arbitration Act; decree in terms of award upheld.

anchor.surface_text: There can be no doubt on the scheme of the Act that any objection even in the nature of a written-statement which falls under s. 30 cannot be considered by the court unless such an objection is made within the period of limitation  namely, 30 days , though if such an objection is made within limitation that objection may in appropriate cases be treated as an application for setting aside the award.
We are of opinion that this appeal must fail.

anchor.surface_text: Assuming that the court has power to set aside the award suo motu, we are of opinion that power cannot be exercised to set aside an award on grounds which fall under s. 30 of the Act, if taken in an objection petition filed more than 30 days after service of notice of filing of the award, for if that were so the limitation provided under Art. 158 of the Limitation Act would be completely negatived.
We are of opinion that this appeal must fail.
